facts.text: Appellant is owner of two bungalows in Navsari: Truth Bungalow and Hill Bungalow.

Truth Bungalow consists of one tenement with a separate room on ground floor in possession of appellant at all material times. Rest let to tenant who surrendered after about one year and quarter, then given to Dr. Bharucha on leave and licence for Rs. 50/- per month in January 1966 or January 1967 (proceeding on January 1967).
Hill Bungalow consists of two tenements: first floor occupied by Soonabai (appellant's mother, aged 82) paying Rs. 50/- per month; lower courts held tenant, High Court held licensee.

Ground floor of Hill Bungalow let to Mahendra Prasad in 1957 at Rs. 65/- per month. He died September 1966, survived by widow (5th respondent), son (1st respondent), daughter (2nd respondent). Respondents 3 and 4 with families resided there prior to death and continued.
2nd and 5th respondents left ground floor premises soon after Mahendra Prasad's death.
Appellant issued notice dated 15th October 1966 terminating tenancy of respondents 1,2,5 for unlawful sub-letting to 3 and 4.
Appellant filed Regular Suit No. 26 of 1967 on 18th January 1967 in Civil Judge, Senior Division, Navsari for possession on ground of unlawful sub-letting under s.13(1)(e) Bombay Rent Act.
Appellant, architect and consulting engineer, retired from Army in 1960, lived in Bombay flat at Rs.475/- month. By mid-1968, work shifted to South Gujarat.
Appellant amended plaint with court leave adding ground of reasonable and bona fide requirement for personal use under s.13(1)(g) Bombay Rent Act.
Respondents 2 and 5 did not contest; main defence by 1,3,4 denying allegations.
Trial court: no unlawful sub-letting proved, but bona fide need and no greater hardship to tenants proved; decree for eviction.
District Judge, Bulsar confirmed decree on appeal.
High Court in revision under s.29(3) Bombay Rent Act reversed: no bona fide need, greater hardship to tenant; dismissed suit. Dated 3rd April 1972.
One room/ garage on ground floor of Hill Bungalow in joint or tenant possession, not usable by appellant for occupation.

legal_issues.text: Scope and ambit of revisional jurisdiction of High Court under s.29(3) Bombay Rent Act: can it interfere with findings of fact by lower courts?
Whether appellant reasonably and bona fide required ground floor premises for personal use and occupation under s.13(1)(g) Bombay Rent Act.
Whether greater hardship would be caused to tenant by eviction than to landlord by refusal under s.13(2) Bombay Rent Act, and burden of proof thereon.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court exceeded jurisdiction under s.29(3) by reversing findings of fact on bona fide requirement and hardship, as they were pure findings of fact without error of law.
Appellant reasonably and bona fide requires premises: shifted work to South Gujarat, high Bombay rent drain, wants to live near mother in Navsari.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied unlawful sub-letting and bona fide requirement.

court_reasoning.text: Revisional jurisdiction under s.29(3) limited to miscarriage of justice due to mistake of law; High Court cannot reappraise evidence and substitute findings of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court exceeded jurisdiction by reappraising evidence on bona fide requirement.

court_reasoning.text: District Judge applied correct test for 'requires' under s.13(1)(g): element of need, not mere desire; finding of bona fide need is fact, unassailable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Truth Bungalow not available due to licensee Dr. Bharucha; cannot compel vacation easily; prefers near mother; Soonabai tenant unlikely to share.

court_reasoning.text: District Judge erred on burden of proof for hardship under s.13(2): both parties must prove hardship; but evidence shows greater hardship to appellant (financial/professional), none for respondent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in finding greater hardship to tenant without evidence.

holdings.text: High Court cannot interfere with factual findings under s.29(3) unless mistake of law; here exceeded on bona fide need.
Appellant reasonably and bona fide requires premises; alternative not practically available.
Burden on both parties for hardship; greater hardship to landlord proven.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdharilal Chaudhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpreted scope of similar revisional provision s.35(1) Delhi Rent Act: limited to mistake of law, not reappraisal of facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj
precedents_cited.relevance: On miscarriage of justice in revision: not mere disagreement with facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s. Central Tobacco Co. v. Chandra Prakash
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden of proof on hardship: both parties must adduce evidence, not shifts entirely to tenant.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Grounds for eviction (sub-letting, bona fide need); greater hardship proviso; revisional jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; trial court decree for eviction restored. Appellant offers one room in Truth Bungalow ground floor to 1st respondent at Rs.15/- month if accepted within 3 months.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for possession of ground floor Hill Bungalow; conditional alternative accommodation offered.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs all throughout.

key_quotes.text: "The High Court cannot reassess the value of the evidence and interfere with a finding of fact merely because it thinks that the appreciation of the evidence by the lower court is wrong."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "What is necessary is that he should need them for his own use and occupation."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Each party must adduce evidence to show what hardship would be caused to him by the granting or refusal of the decree."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Burden of proof on greater hardship.
